Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Randomized Algorithms and Stochastic Models

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The fundamental role played by randomness in computation is one of the key discoveries of research in algorithms and complexity over the last four decades. This manifests itself in at least two ways: through randomized algorithms, and through stochastic models for uncertain data and/or processes. This fundamental role has been accentuated in our Big Data age through tools such as sampling which are vital for streaming and sub-linear algorithms, as well as through the stochasticity that is often inherent in machine learning. In this project, the PI aims to develop or improve some basic techniques in randomized algorithms and stochastic optimization, as well as to apply them to classical and modern problems in combinatorial optimization.

The broader impact of this project will be in several directions including the following. Graduate students will be involved closely in this research, and undergraduate research teams will be exposed to related ideas in algorithms, probabilistic methods, and optimization. High-school students will be taught the foundations of this research, especially the Lovasz Local Lemma and its facets, both through individual mentoring and through group-based teaching. Appropriate aspects of this work will be integrated into the PI's classes. Finally, this work will extend to key applications in areas including vaccination problems and the operation of alternative-energy plants.

This project aims to develop tools that will be general and useful in their own right, as well as techniques that will lead to improvements for targeted, fundamental applications. These applications include well-known problems in combinatorial optimization including asymmetric traveling salesperson, k-median, and stochastic matching, as well as basic issues in application areas such as public health and social networks (vaccination) and alternative energy (operations planning for wind and solar energy plants under stochastic uncertainty). The proposed techniques encompass "going beyond" the powerful Lovasz Local Lemma, new iterated applications of Local Lemma-like techniques and their generalizations to problems such as asymmetric traveling salesperson, the nexus of dependent rounding, submodularity, and (matrix) concentration bounds, as well as new types of differential-equation techniques in discrete optimization. As a particular example, work of the PI and his collaborators has shown that the Moser-Tardos algorithm has facets that can help us get well beyond what is guaranteed by the Lovasz Local Lemma; this project aims to go significantly further in this broad direction, with the goal that generalizations of a powerful tool such as the Local Lemma will have new applications in discrete optimization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Probability has a fundamental connection with modern computer science and data science ? both in the form of randomized algorithms (which make random choices during their execution) and through stochastic models for the inputs to various problems. This project studies fundamental questions within these fields, and also harnesses probabilistic approaches for applications. Some selected outcomes are as follows.

The Lovasz Local Lemma (LLL) is a fundamental probabilistic lemma that has had numerous applications in computer science. The breakthrough of Moser and Tardos from 2009 showed that most applications of the LLL can be made algorithmically efficient. Our work has shown that Moser-Tardos is far more than an algorithmic version of the LLL ? that it is a stochastic process of its own independent merit. As an example, in work with graduated PhD student David Harris that will appear in the Journal of the ACM, we have shown that a classical packet-scheduling problem studied since the 1980s, can be given very efficient schedules for. This follows from one of our (?partial resampling?) generalizations of the Moser-Tardos paradigm.

Distributed and parallel algorithms are fundamentally required in our age of Big Data. This project also makes basic advances in these areas through randomization: e.g.,  or fundamental distributed scheduling problems. Another fascinating aspect of randomized algorithms is that sometimes, the best-known deterministic (i.e., non-randomized) algorithms for some basic problems start by developing an efficient randomized algorithm, and then ?derandomize? it by using a growing body of ?pseudorandomness? approaches. This project also contributes to the toolbox of derandomization approaches in parallel computing.

Fairness is a fundamental requirement in our increasingly algorithms- and machine-learning-driven world. One domain where this is especially true is in the allocation of scarce resources: algorithms could systematically discriminate against certain individuals or demographic groups ? by offering them poor or no resource allocation ? in the service of some global objective function. This project has advanced our understanding of this area by proposing an approach where each user or demographic group can contact for the probability of ?good? service ? which in turn that can be verified for the output of the algorithm using a very short piece of code.

Much of modern E-commerce relies on matching appropriate pairs of entities to each other: showing suitable ads to users arriving over time in digital marketing, the provision of appropriate drivers to arriving passengers in ride-hailing platforms, etc. Stochastic models are very natural here since we cannot predict future arrivals with certainty, but can estimate their probability distributions very well using historical data.  This project has presented several improved online algorithms for such matching problems, and specifically in the domains of digital marketing and ride-share systems. These applications have spurred the development of new (randomized) algorithmic techniques in turn.

The broader impact of this work has been two-fold. First, as in much of fundamental research, we have naturally been guided to formulations and application areas that we had not anticipated at the outset: our work on fairness is a good example of this. Second, this project has aided in the mentoring of students: several Masters and PhD students have benefited from this support, and we have also been able to conduct research with three high-school students. The graduate students have either graduated successfully, or are well on their way to completing strong dissertations. The high-school students have been exposed to modern research in computer science, and each of them has authored published papers and/or won various prizes for their research.
